lead_paragraph: Residents of the nation’s third-largest city, especially blacks and Latinos, have lost faith in many of its essential institutions, a survey finds.

byline.contributor: Monica Davey reported from Chicago, and Giovanni Russonello from New York. Megan Thee-Brenan and Marina Stefan contributed reporting from New York.
byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

headline.print_headline: Chicago Survey Finds Many See City Gone Awry
headline.main: In Deeply Divided Chicago, Most Agree: City Is Off Course

snippet: Residents of the nation’s third-largest city, especially blacks and Latinos, have lost faith in many of its essential institutions, a survey finds.
abstract: New York Times and Kaiser Family Foundation poll finds many residents of Chicago have grown distrustful of city's government, institutions and police and fear city has headed down wrong track; concerns about police brutality, growing rate of violent crime and disapproval of Mayor Rahm Emanuel are most pronounced among black residents.
